The Egyptian artist Nima Nabi has been awarded the Florence Prize for his installation Breaking the Silence, 2018–2019, which was staged at the Museo d’Arte Moderno in Florence and won the prize for best work in a single category. Nabi, a Palestinian-born Egyptian artist who also works as a sculptor, filmmaker, and activist, was presented with the award by the prize jury on Monday, which also awarded the prize to the Egyptian-born writer Nima Nabi for his contribution to the “Arab Spring.”Nabi’s latest work, “Breaking the Silence,” which is part of a series called “Planes,” is an open-concept installation that unfolds like a poem and invites the viewer to imagine the experiences of a group of strangers as they pass by in a plane. The open-concept art project, which was inspired by Nabi’s own experiences, is part of an ongoing series examining the meaning and function of language.
